#Text=EXPLANATORY

#Text=IN this book a number of dialects are used , to wit : the Missouri negro dialect ; the extremest form of the backwoods Southwestern dialect ; the ordinary “ Pike County ” dialect ; and four modified varieties of this last .

#Text=The shadings have not been done in a haphazard fashion , or by guesswork ; but painstakingly , and with the trustworthy guidance and support of personal familiarity with these several forms of speech .
#Text=I make this explanation for the reason that without it many readers would suppose that all these characters were trying to talk alike and not succeeding .
#Text=THE AUTHOR .
#Text=HUCKLEBERRY FINN
#Text=Scene : The Mississippi Valley Time : Forty to fifty years ago
#Text=CHAPTER I.
#Text=YOU do n't know about me without you have read a book by the name of The Adventures of Tom Sawyer ; but that ai n't no matter .
#Text=That book was made by Mr. Mark Twain , and he told the truth , mainly .
#Text=There was things which he stretched , but mainly he told the truth .
#Text=That is nothing .
#Text=I never seen anybody but lied one time or another , without it was Aunt Polly , or the widow , or maybe Mary .
#Text=Aunt Polly -- Tom 's Aunt Polly , she is -- and Mary , and the Widow Douglas is all told about in that book , which is mostly a true book , with some stretchers , as I said before .
#Text=Now the way that the book winds up is this : Tom and me found the money that the robbers hid in the cave , and it made us rich .
#Text=We got six thousand dollars apiece -- all gold .
#Text=It was an awful sight of money when it was piled up .
#Text=Well , Judge Thatcher he took it and put it out at interest , and it fetched us a dollar a day apiece all the year round -- more than a body could tell what to do with .

#Text=The Widow Douglas she took me for her son , and allowed she would sivilize me ; but it was rough living in the house all the time , considering how dismal regular and decent the widow was in all her ways ; and so when I could n't stand it no longer I lit out .
#Text=I got into my old rags and my sugar-hogshead again , and was free and satisfied .
#Text=But Tom Sawyer he hunted me up and said he was going to start a band of robbers , and I might join if I would go back to the widow and be respectable .
#Text=So I went back .
#Text=The widow she cried over me , and called me a poor lost lamb , and she called me a lot of other names , too , but she never meant no harm by it .
#Text=She put me in them new clothes again , and I could n't do nothing but sweat and sweat , and feel all cramped up .
#Text=Well , then , the old thing commenced again .
#Text=The widow rung a bell for supper , and you had to come to time .

#Text=When you got to the table you could n't go right to eating , but you had to wait for the widow to tuck down her head and grumble a little over the victuals , though there war n't really anything the matter with them , -- that is , nothing only everything was cooked by itself .
#Text=In a barrel of odds and ends it is different ; things get mixed up , and the juice kind of swaps around , and the things go better .

#Text=After supper she got out her book and learned me about Moses and the Bulrushers , and I was in a sweat to find out all about him ; but by and by she let it out that Moses had been dead a considerable long time ; so then I did n't care no more about him , because I do n't take no stock in dead people .
#Text=Pretty soon I wanted to smoke , and asked the widow to let me .
#Text=But she would n't .
#Text=She said it was a mean practice and was n't clean , and I must try to not do it any more .
#Text=That is just the way with some people .
#Text=They get down on a thing when they do n't know nothing about it .
#Text=Here she was a-bothering about Moses , which was no kin to her , and no use to anybody , being gone , you see , yet finding a power of fault with me for doing a thing that had some good in it .
#Text=And she took snuff , too ; of course that was all right , because she done it herself .
#Text=Her sister , Miss Watson , a tolerable slim old maid , with goggles on , had just come to live with her , and took a set at me now with a spelling-book .
#Text=She worked me middling hard for about an hour , and then the widow made her ease up .
#Text=I could n't stood it much longer .
#Text=Then for an hour it was deadly dull , and I was fidgety .

#Text=Miss Watson would say , “ Do n't put your feet up there , Huckleberry ; ” and “ Do n't scrunch up like that , Huckleberry -- set up straight ; ” and pretty soon she would say , “ Do n't gap and stretch like that , Huckleberry -- why do n't you try to behave ? ”
#Text=Then she told me all about the bad place , and I said I wished I was there .
#Text=She got mad then , but I did n't mean no harm .
#Text=All I wanted was to go somewheres ; all I wanted was a change , I war n't particular .
#Text=She said it was wicked to say what I said ; said she would n't say it for the whole world ; she was going to live so as to go to the good place .
#Text=Well , I could n't see no advantage in going where she was going , so I made up my mind I would n't try for it .
#Text=But I never said so , because it would only make trouble , and would n't do no good .
